Mark Bellison.Action: Narrates and empathizes with the 'loser caveman,' highlighting his vulnerability and eventual bravery.
Takes decisive action to confront and kill the beast after initially being seen as a coward.
Uses a lie to alter the perception of others and gain status.
Introduces himself awkwardly to Jennifer and tries to engage in conversation despite her blunt rejection.
Expresses hope that the date ends in sex, showing a straightforward but perhaps insensitive attitude.
Admits feeling awkward and regretful about being early, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Pulls up and parks his car, finds Jennifer's apartment, and confidently knocks on the door.
Engages in awkward and blunt conversation, including stating 'That makes me think of your vagina' and openly expressing hopes for sex, which makes the interaction uncomfortable.
Admits feeling awkward and regrets being early, showing self-awareness but also poor social timing.
Admits insecurity about financial situation and relationship history honestly to Jennifer
Engages in candid, humorous but somewhat awkward exchange with Jennifer
Does not put on a false front or try to impress Jennifer with lies or boasting
Admits he doesn't know the latest, hippest restaurants, showing humility.
Shows disinterest when Jennifer talks at length about herself, focusing instead on fish tacos.
Admits to not knowing the hippest restaurants when asked.
Changes the topic internally when conversation becomes boring, thinking about fish tacos instead.
Efficiently orders two meals from the hostess without hesitation.
Engages in light-hearted banter with the waiter and Jennifer, acknowledging social hierarchy realistically without malice.
Admits to only listening to half of what Jennifer is saying.
Responds succinctly to the waiter, ordering a Budweiser without hesitation.
Acknowledges the waiter's comment about Jennifer being out of his league with a simple 'Yup,' showing acceptance without defensiveness.
Admits to only really listening to about half of Jennifer's answers, indicating partial engagement and inattentiveness.
Asks Jennifer straightforward, basic questions about her daily life and job without deeper insight or creativity.
Shows interest in Jennifer by encouraging her to share more about herself and trying to gain insight into her.
Tries to get insight into Jennifer by asking questions and listening.
Orders fish tacos because it's all he knows at the restaurant.
Thanks Jennifer for going on the date, acknowledges insecurity about differences in social status.
Leans in for a kiss after Jennifer expresses uncertainty, accepts a kiss on the cheek graciously.
Thanks Jennifer for going on the date and acknowledges she is out of his league, showing awareness and humility.
Leans in for a kiss but accepts a kiss on the cheek without showing frustration or anger.
Engages in polite conversation and handles the situation with Jennifer's mother’s phone call calmly.
Makes no attempt to escalate or pressure Jennifer beyond polite boundaries.
Shouting after Jennifer as she enters her apartment, potentially indicating awkwardness or poor social timing.
Mark's bedroom is bland and furnished cheaply; he passively watches TV commercials and falls asleep with the TV on.
Groggily wakes up with nothing to look forward to, sighs deeply, indicating low motivation and initiative.
Greets Frank politely despite both being in low spirits, nods and says 'See you tomorrow.'
Responds apologetically to road rage from honking man by waving, showing patience and tolerance.
Shares honestly about his failed date and potential firing, showing self-awareness but no active problem-solving.
Acknowledges others politely (nods goodbye to Frank), demonstrating social awareness and basic courtesy.
Drives carefully and apologetically when honked at, indicating awareness and reasonable driving skills.
Passively listens to others' conversations and situations without engaging or taking initiative.
Parks car and walks confidently into the building despite distractions and unusual happenings outside.
Nods understandingly to the woman expressing apprehension, showing social awareness but no direct skill use.
Walks through lobby seemingly without reacting to the boring and depressing environment, showing focus but no advanced competence.
Dejectedly waves to the tour, acknowledges his status honestly.
Greets Shelley with a friendly, somewhat flirtatious comment.
Responds calmly to Shelley's blunt criticism without anger.
Shows some concern about missed work calls and the situation.
Does not confront Shelley aggressively despite her harshness.
Requests Anthony not to fire him, showing vulnerability.
Insists on facing the firing now rather than later to avoid putting Anthony in discomfort.
Responds to Shelley's hostility with a humorous, slightly self-deprecating comment.
Acknowledges Jennifer's rejection calmly and compliments her writing.
Does not retaliate against Rob's insults; accepts harsh treatment without anger.
Takes his grandmother by the hand and moves her to a more comfortable position.
Patiently explains the TV channel issue to his confused grandmother.
Admits he doesn't understand his grandmother's feelings and expresses frustration but follows with love and a wish for things to improve.
Shares his own failures and feelings of loneliness honestly with his grandmother.
Harshly calls his grandmother a loser and generalizes their family negatively.
Expresses a strong desire to change his situation and acknowledges the need to find a job.
Declares he will start looking for a job tomorrow rather than immediately taking action.
Shows emotional honesty and self-awareness by admitting feelings of being a 'loser'.
Admits his average, generic nature with humility.
Expresses a sincere wish to have a better friend than Greg.
Feels compassion but also self-deprecates in front of Greg.
Ends conversation to avoid further depressing his friend.
Calls Jennifer but is too scared to speak, then quickly apologizes and hangs up.
Expresses self-awareness about his average qualities and seemingly accepts his limitations.
Decides to look for another job despite bleak prospects, showing persistence.
Stumbles drunkenly out of the bar and struggles to communicate on the phone due to nervousness and embarrassment.
Admits to being unemployed and unable to pay rent honestly to the landlord.
Shows frustration and rage at his situation without blaming others explicitly.
Tosses alarm clock across the room, goes back to bed after waking up.
Admits honestly to landlord about being fired and not having rent money.
Stands helpless as belongings are pushed out into hallway, shows no resistance or attempt to negotiate.
Grits teeth in rage after landlord tells him to rent a truck with limited money, but does not take any immediate effective action.
Openly admits to being evicted and potentially homeless to the bank teller.
Feels internal struggle and embarrassment before stating his balance to the bank teller.
Struggles internally but gathers himself to answer the teller's questions with specific info.
Initially appears unsure and hesitant when trying to make a withdrawal.
Demonstrates increasing confidence and presence of mind under pressure.
Nervously smiles awkwardly at other tellers after realizing the discrepancy in his bank account
Breaks out in a cold sweat and does not lie or argue about his withdrawal amount despite knowing he only has $300
Hurries away after receiving the unexpected eight hundred dollars without causing a scene or taking advantage
Claims to have eight hundred dollars in his account when he only has three hundred, leading to nervousness and inability to respond when confronted.
Stays silent and awkward rather than trying to explain or correct the discrepancy when challenged.
Accepts the money in shock and quickly leaves without causing a scene or escalating the situation.
Pays his rent honestly despite awkwardness with landlord.
Lies to landlord about where money came from.
Excitedly shares his discovery candidly with Greg, showing openness.
Pays rent promptly by bringing money to landlord, demonstrating responsibility.
Quickly improvises a lie about finding money on the street to explain source of unexpected cash, showing situational quick-thinking.
Struggles to find the right words to explain the concept of lying to Greg, hesitating and pausing multiple times.
Engages friends in playful conversation, inventing new identities and sharing humor.
Expresses frustration and anger by punching the bar.
Attempts to demonstrate his new ability to lie, trying various false statements to test reactions.
Struggles to explain the concept he invented and is initially frustrated by his inability to communicate it clearly.
Uses experimentation and persistence to figure out how people respond to his lies, showing adaptability.
Gets flustered and resorts to random and implausible lies (claiming to be black, Eskimo, pirate, lion tamer) which do not convince or confuse his audience.
Engages Greg and Jim in playful imaginative conversation, tries to prompt them to think about what they would do with power.
Gets bored and gives up on the conversation, then leaves the bar dejected.
Listens to Greg and Jim's crude desires without criticizing, appears tolerant despite discomfort.
Heads outside nervously when seeing an attractive woman, showing social anxiety or awkwardness rather than engaging her.
Gives up on the game and admits boredom; fails to convincingly engage or lead the activity.
Attempts to prompt others to think about changing the world by asking what they would do first, showing some initiative.
Decides to try to make the other's wishes come true, showing some decisiveness and openness to action.
On seeing a potential romantic interest, freezes and fails to act confidently or skillfully, like a 'deer in the headlights'.
Stares at the blonde like a deer in headlights, unable to respond confidently.
Blurts out an extreme and desperate statement to the blonde ('THE WORLD IS GOING TO END IF WE DON'T HAVE SEX RIGHT NOW!'), showing poor social judgment.
Feels guilt and revulsion after realizing the unintended emotional impact on the blonde; recognizes something is wrong and pulls away.
Calms the panicked blonde by calling NASA and reassuring her with factual news.
Shows empathy and attempts to comfort a distressed person.
Recognizes his negative behavior by calling himself an asshole, showing self-awareness.
Leaves the blonde despite her request for him to stay, potentially showing poor social judgment or avoidance.
Encourages Greg to go on a trip despite both being drunk, shares shots with him.
Shows concern and tries to intervene when the cop approaches Greg about the Breathalyzer test.
Nudges Greg to keep him awake and engaged despite Greg nodding off.
Decides to take three shots himself and then announces going on a trip while drunk.
Expresses worry when police approach after Greg drives drunk.
Attempts to intervene when cop is about to administer Breathalyzer to Greg.
Intervenes when Greg is accused of being drunk to prevent unjust arrest.
Offers to drive Greg despite appearing intoxicated himself, prioritizing Greg's safety.
Laughs after successfully handling the situation but reassures Greg he will be all right, showing friendly and supportive behavior.
Convinces the cop that Greg is not drunk despite high Breathalyzer reading, showing quick thinking and confidence.
Successfully takes control of the situation by suggesting he drive, demonstrating situational awareness and decisiveness.
Laughs after crisis without apparent concern for Greg's condition, which may reflect a lack of empathy or seriousness.
Invites and includes Greg in going to the Bellagio despite financial worries.
Confidently and patiently responds to warnings about gambling risks, showing acceptance.
Orders drinks for both himself and Greg, considering Greg's condition.
Ignores Greg's negative opinion about roulette and encourages optimism.
Pays for chips despite knowing the odds and risks, proceeds to gamble at roulette showing confidence.
Ignores Greg's objection that roulette is purely chance with no skill, but still commits to the bet decisively.
Slides everyone else's chips into a giant pile and claims them as his own.
Notices confusion in others around him and suggests moving to play slots instead of pushing his luck further.
Politely thanks the Pit Man after he fixes the slot machine problem.
Engages in playful and collaborative conversation with Greg, humorously discussing impossible scenarios.
Greets his depressive neighbor Frank sincerely and inquires about his wellbeing.
Responds politely and positively to Frank despite Frank's obvious distress.
Suggests putting money on a specific number for a higher payoff instead of just on black.
Identifies a logical flaw in the plan about betting all the money in the world and how paying out would be impossible.
Understands the implications of owning all casinos and how betting against themselves is ultimately futile.
Engages with Greg's illogical plan to break their own fingers without challenging its absurdity.
Stops Frank from committing suicide by expressing care and offering hope about the future.
Reluctantly agrees to hang out with Frank despite initial hesitation.
Persuasively convinces Frank not to commit suicide, showing emotional intelligence and influence.
Initially responds to Frank’s suicide comment with awkwardness and minimal engagement ('Oh. All right. Bye, Frank.'), showing limited social confidence.
Despite initial awkwardness, persists in encouraging Frank, offering hopeful reassurances clearly and calmly.
Is unsure about hanging out but agrees to do so to not disappoint Frank, indicating some social uncertainty.
Does various good deeds throughout the day using his discovery.
Comforts and helps the homeless man, gaining his trust so he can take him to the bank.
Encourages a woman who was reluctant to go to work, resulting in her smiling and going happily.
Writes down his discovery carefully and considers the consequences of his invention, showing foresight and caution.
Uses his discovery to perform positive actions like helping the homeless man and persuading a woman to go to work, demonstrating effective application of new knowledge.
Expresses uncertainty and fear about controlling the newfound power, acknowledging his limitations.
Intervenes to reconcile a fighting couple, bringing them back together happily.
Walks through an elderly home, whispering to residents and leaving them smiling or tearful in a touching way.
Cautiously reflects on the potential risks of his discovery, acknowledging his limited understanding and the need for care.
Successfully reconciles an arguing couple by communicating with each individually, leading to a positive emotional outcome.
Explains the concept of his invention logically and clearly, showing understanding of its function and implications.
Interacts compassionately with elderly people, making them happy and emotionally moved.
Encourages others to experiment with his invention, showing confidence and enthusiasm.
Writes a reflective letter about his invention and hides it safely for the future, indicating foresight and responsibility.
Calls Jennifer to ask her out again despite previous rejection, acknowledges his past flaws, and earnestly requests one more chance.
Uses sarcasm in response to Jennifer's pessimistic comment about their last date.
Hangs up happily after phone call with Jennifer despite a somewhat awkward exchange.
Mocks writer Rob Marlowe's streak of success ending.
Realizes a problem or gap in current knowledge/behavior and immediately takes initiative by writing intensely through the night to address it.
Initially struggles to find the right words or express himself clearly on the phone, indicating some hesitation or lack of confidence.

Ignores Shelley’s terrified comment and does not engage with her.
Walks past Rob’s insults without reaction, staying silent.
Opens the door to Anthony James, who is fearful and self-deprecating, indicating Mark is seen as a threat.
Hustles through the parking lot with manuscript in hand, then deliberately dirties it to create a convincing prop before entering the office.
Maintains focus despite hostile and mocking behavior from colleagues Shelley and Rob.
Approaches and opens the door to the Head of Development's office without hesitation, showing initiative and confidence.
Reassures Anthony that he is not mad about firing, easing his anxiety.
Shares personal story of depression and discovery with Anthony, showing openness and willingness to connect.
Invites Anthony to get excited about the manuscript, attempting to engage him positively.
Finds and digs up an ancient manuscript and confidently presents it as a new historical story.
Appears depressed and remotely disconnected after being fired before suddenly discovering the manuscript.

Reads a heartfelt, joyous story that moves the audience to tears and applause; is humble despite success and shows magnanimity when being embraced by others.
Thankful and appreciative to Jennifer for dinner and her company, smiling sincerely.

Takes a moment to think over what to say before answering Rob.
Receives massive applause and admiration from others, indicating confidence and recognition.
Internalizes mockery and firing by boss Anthony and peers Rob and Shelly but ultimately turns situation around.
Expresses plans to buy his grandmother a mansion to improve her quality of life.
Describes family misfortune and tragedy but shows some hope and care for relatives.
Summons courage to express his romantic interest in Jennifer despite uncertain outcome.
Attempts to rationally explain potential benefits of a romantic relationship and family life.
Accepts Jennifer's blunt rejection without argument, showing social awkwardness.
Smoothly acknowledges disappointing feedback with a simple nod and agreement.
Responds confidently when asked about food quality despite waiter’s insult.
Face melts in terror upon receiving phone call, indicating possible loss of composure or bad news.
Bursts into the hospital room immediately after receiving distressing news and asks direct questions about his grandmother's condition.
Sits next to his grandmother in shock and appears emotionally overwhelmed, showing difficulty processing the situation.
Calmly comforts his scared grandmother facing death by inventing a hopeful and loving afterlife story to ease her pain.

Sits silently with Jennifer, allowing her to comfort him gently and staying present without pushing her away.
Allows Jennifer to hold his wrist while they fall asleep on the couch, sharing a gentle, quiet moment.
Feels overwhelmed but tries to address the crowd's desperate questions instead of ignoring them.
Initially pushes through the crowd somewhat brusquely and asks 'Who are you people?', showing slight detachment.
Is overwhelmed by the crowd demanding answers and manages to push through them to enter his building, asking who they are first.

Seems mentally overwhelmed and retreats to his apartment, pulling out a beer, indicating difficulty handling the stress promptly.
Picks up phone and explains his situation honestly to Jennifer, invites her over to help.
Opens door for Jennifer and urges her to come inside quickly for her safety.
Screens a phone call before answering, showing caution and awareness of his situation.

Admits confusion and inability to fully explain the situation to Jennifer, showing limited confidence and clarity.
Says 'Fuck' upon hearing the news on TV, indicating panic or frustration, suggesting lack of emotional control.
Considers leaving the situation entirely by going to Namibia to avoid consequences.
Keeps his secret despite great pressure, showing hesitation and uncertainty about consequences.
Comforts his dying grandmother with a hopeful lie that brings her peace.
Feels conflicted and doubts the rightness of his actions after seeing their impact.
Considers carefully before sharing his discovery with others, seeks time to prepare.
Accepts Greg's friendly gesture of bringing pizza and interacts casually.
Thinks over the significance of his task before proceeding; asks Jennifer if he is sure about the rightness of the decision.
Sits down, organizes his thoughts by writing out his announcement carefully and thoroughly.
Does not immediately rush into making the announcement; takes time to prepare mentally and practically.
Seeks support from Jennifer and Greg before addressing the world, shows nervousness and vulnerability.
Uses torn pizza boxes as makeshift tablets to hold his manuscript, accepts help and improvises with friendliness and humility.
Steps out to face a silent, expectant crowd and prepares to share important information.
Acknowledges the crowd's hope and neediness with a sincere look.
Makes up answers to crowd's unprepared questions to maintain their faith and trust.
Tells others an encouraging story about an afterlife with mansions and loved ones, including options for living together.
Says those you hate will not be in the afterlife.
Confidently provides clear, simple explanations to a crowd and keeps them engaged.
Admits when he does not know an answer (e.g., about the kind of mansion, what happens to mansions when someone leaves).
Struggles to answer follow-up questions thoroughly, providing vague or incomplete answers.
Gives explanations to the crowd about love and the afterlife, trying to comfort and clarify.
Responds to silly or skeptical questions with mild frustration but continues engaging with the crowd.
Gets annoyed and somewhat impatient when the crowd persists with seemingly naive or repetitive questions.
Explains the concept of an afterlife with rules and consequences in a clear, confident manner to the crowd.
Responds to skeptical or challenging questions from the crowd without hesitation or confusion.
Dismisses concerns with overly simplistic or slightly rude answers (e.g., 'Well don't eat it then!', 'What's wrong with you people?').
Answers moral questions patiently to a large crowd, even after many repetitive and trivial questions.
Shows frustration and asks the crowd to move on.
Calms a terrified crowd by reassuring them they are fine if they did not know their past bad actions were wrong before he told them.
Creates a new religious doctrine by confidently stating the man in the sky causes all disasters and controls life and death.
Acknowledges painful truths (e.g., illnesses, accidents caused by the man in the sky) honestly to the crowd despite likely negative reaction.
Fails to foresee or manage the negative backlash from the crowd against the man in the sky after revealing harsh truths.
Interrupts angry crowd and introduces a more balanced perspective about the 'man in the sky', acknowledging both good and bad deeds.
Honestly admits that the 'man in the sky' caused harm as well as good, rather than lying to appease the crowd.
Calmly interrupts a volatile crowd to present a complex explanation that balances negative and positive aspects, successfully calming them down and gaining their attention.
Thinks quickly on his feet when confronted with unexpected crowd hostility, coming up with a persuasive narrative that satisfies and intrigues the crowd.
Takes Jennifer by the hand and pulls her inside the building after an exhausting event.
Jokingly says 'The man in the clouds told me' when questioned about his knowledge.
Admits not knowing why people are just learning these things now and ends the talk abruptly to leave the crowd.
Pulls Jennifer by the hand to leave the scene quickly after his speech.

Is recognized publicly with headlines and achievements including 'Man of the Year,' indicating societal recognition of his impact.
Removes the 'For Sale' sign from his new home; Jennifer and Greg congratulate him.

Laughs and enjoys time with Jennifer and Greg in a limousine, attending a movie premiere together.

Sits disheveled and messy in his mansion, drinking beer surrounded by empty cans, seemingly neglecting self-care.
Engages in imaginative storytelling aloud while a young man writes it down attentively.
Does not react to Jennifer's concern about fence climbers and security, remaining passive.
Jennifer grabs the beer out of Mark's hand to stop his drinking.
Glaring at Jennifer and continuing to drink despite her concern.
Shows playful storytelling with the assistant, engaging in a whimsical tale.
Yells at assistant in a somewhat childish manner ('Tell them it's for kids!').
Is disengaged and isolated, refusing to leave the house despite Jennifer's urging.
Shrugs and shows sadness when Jennifer expresses concern.
Expresses sincere affection by saying he'd trade all his success for Jennifer.
Engages in honest, gentle self-deprecating humor about his genetics and their impact on a relationship.
Considers telling a lie to comfort Jennifer but ultimately chooses to be truthful about their situation.
Tells Jennifer that Rob Marlowe is a 'complete and total asshole' and tries to discourage Jennifer from going out with him.
Compliments Jennifer indirectly by saying 'a shark would be nice to you' and 'look at you,' indicating high regard for her.
Expresses frustration and disappointment about Jennifer's choices and feelings, showing emotional investment in her well-being.
Rejects the idea of moving into Jennifer's mansion with her and Rob, indicating resistance to forced closeness or insincerity.

Immediately confronts Jennifer about her date and tries to dissuade her from going out with Rob Marlowe by arguing and pointing out negative traits about Rob.
Gets visibly upset and struggles to articulate coherent arguments, pausing and backtracking in conversation.
Shows emotional impulsiveness by reacting with anger and frustration instead of calm persuasion.
Sits down and states 'It's like nothing's changed' after the conversation, reflecting passive resignation rather than taking proactive steps.
Attempts to understand the situation by asking direct questions (e.g., 'What? With who?', 'What's he got that I don't?').
Covers the negative Coke warning label and tells Greg that drinking Coke and other forbidden foods could be good for you, making Greg hopeful and happy.
Acknowledges that warning labels can be depressing and people hate thinking about horrible things.
Proposes a positive rebranding of products to make people feel better.
Prepares and delivers a confident, well-organized business presentation with a slideshow, proposing a novel, innovative marketing concept to executives.
Effectively addresses the executives' concerns by emphasizing the positive impact of removing negative warnings.
Sighs and admits he didn't actually create the healthy Coke or safe plane, just changed the appearance.
Encourages executives to deceive customers by printing false claims on products to boost sales.
Convincingly presents a strategy to executives by changing only packaging and relying on perception to boost sales, and explains it clearly despite others not fully understanding the details.
Admits to not actually inventing or changing the products, just the presentation, showing honesty and practical thinking.
Calmly manages the executive’s excitement and questions with straightforward answers, maintaining control of the conversation.
Encourages executives by highlighting the positive emotional impact of products, aiming to make people less scared or bummed out.
Makes a lighthearted, humorous comment about 'five thousand gay orphans on my front lawn that are going bananas' before leaving the room.
Successfully convinces executives to adopt and promote new products with positive messaging, leading to widespread consumer enthusiasm and increased sales.
Confidently departs after sealing the deal, showing an ability to navigate social situations with charm (e.g., humorous remark about the orphans).
Warns Greg not to overeat despite marketing claims, showing concern for his well-being.
Declines Greg's offered brownie politely, showing reluctant sadness but does not burden Greg with explanation.
Advises Greg to slow down on eating cookies despite the package claims, showing critical thinking.
Sighs and seems sad or resigned rather than confidently engaging or offering a solution.
Confronts honking man about rudeness, expects apology.
Reflects honestly and sincerely at grandmother's grave about his loneliness and deception.

Engages confidently with the honking man, asking for an apology.
Feels unhappy and isolated despite success, showing inability to find personal fulfillment.
Invites Jennifer in despite recent distance in their relationship.
Tells Jennifer not to marry another man, showing concern and care for her happiness.
Shrugs off the wedding invitation with 'No point really.', appearing dismissive or resigned.
Searches for a bottle opener but is distracted by an envelope labeled 'MY INVENTION' and reacts cautiously when someone enters.
Tells Jennifer not to marry someone else and encourages her to be with him despite knowing her practical reasons for marriage.
Dismisses Jennifer's wedding invitation with a shrug and comments 'No point really,' showing resignation.
Assures Jennifer that she won't become old, wrinkly, and ugly to him, expressing sincere love and acceptance beyond appearances.
Encourages Jennifer to think for herself and not just follow societal expectations, showing respect and genuine care for her individuality.
Admits he wants Jennifer and expresses willingness to step away if her desires differ, demonstrating honesty and respect for her autonomy.
Asks Jennifer to stay a little longer so he won't be alone, revealing vulnerability and a desire for companionship.
Does not react negatively or confront Jennifer after she reads his letter and leaves scared and confused, indicating restraint and respect for her feelings.
Encourages Jennifer to think independently and question societal norms instead of blindly accepting them.
Expresses his feelings clearly and asks Jennifer to honestly consider what she wants.
Invites Jennifer to stay despite initial rejection, showing social awareness and vulnerability.
Falls asleep on the couch while Jennifer reads his letter and feels scared and confused.
Watches Jennifer in awe, stunned by her beauty, quietly observes her walking down the aisle.
Dresses appropriately in a suit and tie, gets ready on time with awareness of being late.
Passively watches Jennifer walk down the aisle in awe, allowing Rob to mock him without response.
Perks up and pays close attention when Jennifer questions Rob during the wedding ceremony.
Volunteers himself as a better genetic match in front of the room, confidently challenges Rob, and expresses his genuine feelings to Jennifer, attempting to influence her decision.
After Jennifer shows uncertainty, Mark quickly decides to leave awkwardly without further clarifying or resolving the tension, showing some indecisiveness or avoidance.
Admits to lying about the Man in the Sky to protect his grandmother's feelings.
Reassures Jennifer that she will always be beautiful to him, regardless of her looks.
Shares a vulnerable moment of mutual confusion and difficulty with Jennifer.
Responds joyfully and supportively when Jennifer expresses her desire for children.
Admits honestly that he lied about the 'Man in the Sky' because he couldn't cope with his grandmother's expression.
Expresses sincere and clear feelings to Jennifer about beauty and love, showing emotional intelligence.
Feels overwhelmed and admits that everything is hard and not easy anymore.
Responds enthusiastically and confidently to Jennifer's expressed desire for 'short, fat kids,' indicating a positive, easy-going, and confident attitude.
Confirms that no one else knows about his invention but anticipates that it won't be long before others do, showing some awareness of implications but no clear plan revealed.
Expresses hesitation about sharing his invention with others, showing consideration of others' understanding.
Smiles at Jennifer and walks hand in hand with her toward the church, indicating affection and connection.
Expresses uncertainty about whether everyone will understand the invention of lying.
